Cobalt doped ZnS nanoparticles as a recyclable catalyst for solvent-free synthesis of heterocyclic privileged medicinal scaffolds under infrared irradiation Anshu Dandia a â Vijay Parewa a Shyam L. Graphical abstract Highlights âº ZnS and Co doped ZnS NPs through the wet chemical method (particle size 5nm and 4nm respectively). âº Nanocatalyst can play a dual role of catalyst as well as susceptor. âº Doping of Co promotes the activity and selectivity of ZnS NPs. âº Synthesis of pyrazolones (with excellent regioselectivity) and 1,3-oxathiolan-5-one frameworks. âº High catalytic activity in terms of TOF by Co doping could be attributed to an increase of surface acidity. This paper reports preparation and characterization of cobalt doped ZnS NPs and their catalytic application in the synthesis of heterocyclic privileged medicinal scaffolds involving pyrazolones (with excellent regioselectivity) and 1,3-oxathiolan-5-one frameworks under infrared irradiation. Nanoparticles have been prepared at room temperature by a wet chemical method. The heterogeneous catalysts were fully characterized by XRD, TEM, EDAX, ICP-AES and UV/Vis. Under infrared radiation (IR), the catalytic activity of Co doped ZnS NPs was about 40-fold higher under IR as compared to the conventional method. Nanocatalyst plays a dual role of catalyst as well as susceptor, and enhances the overall capacity to absorb IR in the reaction mixture. Doping by Co promotes the activity and selectivity of ZnS NPs as indicated by their high TOF value, providing the products with good to excellent yields. The surface acidity of NPs was measured by FTIR spectra of chemisorbed pyridine. The present method does not involve any hazardous organic solvent or catalyst. The introduction of nanocatalyst in an IR system offers promising features for the reaction response such as the shorter reaction time, simple work-up procedure, and purification of products by non-chromatographic methods. The catalyst was reused up to four runs without an appreciable loss of catalytic activity. Keywords Heterogeneous catalyst Doping Cobalt doped ZnS NPs Privileged structures Pyrazolones Regioselectivity 1,3-Oxathiolan-5-one Infrared irradiation 1 Introduction The search for privileged structures is rapidly becoming a crucial component of strategy in drug discovery as they represent an ideal source of lead compounds [1,2]. Further it involves the utilization of molecular frameworks with inherent potential for biological activity. Therefore, through appropriate functional group modifications, these scaffolds are capable of providing ligands for a number of functionally and structurally discrete biological receptors. Moreover, pyrazoles are privileged heterocyclic scaffolds. Diversification at C3 and C4 positions of pyrazolone core has produced a large number of compound libraries. Instances of the recent development of the pharmacophores possessing pyrazole (Fig. 1 ) as the core unit [3â6] include a potent antitumor inhibitors cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK), monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) inhibitors, neuroprotective, estrogen receptor, Celebrex, Viagra etc. Besides, 1,3-oxathiolan-5-one scaffolds have also been successfully utilized for the generation of libraries for diverse medicinal applications (Fig. 1). They are intermediates for the synthesis of many bioactive compounds [7]. To exemplify, derivatives of 1,3-oxathiolan-5-ones can be used as building blocks for the preparation of the oxathiolanyl-nucleoside Coviracil [8,9] and polyfunctionalized bicyclicpyrimidines, which are of industrial as well as biological importance [10]. 2-Amino-1,3-thiazines and their derivatives with antibacterial, antitumor, insecticidal, and fungicidal activities have also been prepared using 2-methyl-2-phenyl-1,3-oxathiolan-5-one [11]. Thus, the potentialities of this class of compounds have led to them being encountered through the development of various synthetic protocols. The classical methodologies employed for pyrazole synthesis involve 1,3-dipolar cycloadditions [12,13], Suzuki coupling [14], N-arylation [15,16], etc. The most common access to this structural motif is Knorr condensation [17â19]. In addition, several catalysts [20â22] such as H2SO4, polystyrene supported sulfonic acid, layered zirconium sulfophenyl phosphonate, Sc(OTf)3, and Y-zeolite have been employed to affect this transformation. Due to the larger applicability of the products formed in Knorr condensation, some environmentally benign modification of the above condensation has also been documented [23,22]. 1,3-Oxathiolan-5-ones and their derivatives have been synthesized conventionally from disconnection approach using synthetic equivalents; a derivative of a ketone and mercaptoacetic acid employing vigorous heating with PTSA [24], dimethyltin diiodideâHMPTA complex [25], LiBr [26], zinc chloride [27] as a catalyst. In spite of there being a subtle upliftment of the reaction conditions through these strategies, somewhere down the line they still lack the versatility. The most concerning outcome is the detrimental effect of environmentally non-compatible solvent. Secondly, the used catalytic systems are usually non-recoverable, thereby reducing the turn over number (TON) or turn over frequency (TOF), which is important from the industrial point of view. However, some of these methods often involve strong acid-catalyzed conditions that limit functional group tolerance. Further, transition metal-catalyzed methods pose a threat of contamination of toxic metals with the product, co-occurrence of several side reactions and by-products, use of expensive, toxic, and explosive (LiBr) reagents. Since the aforesaid conditions are not compatible with heat or acid sensitive substrates, there is a compelling need to develop an effective synthetic procedure under more eco-friendly conditions. Infrared and nanocatalysts are two important and rapidly developing technologies in green chemistry, and these two environmentally benign methods have been employed to accelerate organic reaction separately [28â32]. Many attempts have been made to improve the performance of nanoparticles as a catalyst, and different transition metals such as Co, Fe, and Mn have been investigated as promoter elements to develop new or improved catalytic system [33]. Promoters are doping agents added to catalyst materials in small amounts to improve their activity, selectivity and/or stability [34]. Cobalt nanoparticles are expected to possess excellent magnetic, hardness and impact resistance properties. In addition, Co based nanocatalysts have attracted a great deal of attention in the past [35â37], where these nanocatalysts play important roles in the chemical industry. Development of novel synthetic methodology to facilitate the preparation of compound libraries based on privileged structures is an intense area of research. One approach to address this challenge involves the development of nano-catalysis. The amalgamation of nonconventional heating with nanocatalysts seems to be highly efficient for developing future generation chemical processes [38,39]. Hence, arbitrating the rationale behind the development of a versatile and sustainable methodology and our interest in the exploration of expeditious synthesis of nanoparticles and heterocyclic compounds [40â44], herein we wish to demonstrate that the combination of cobalt doped ZnS NPs and IR is an efficient method for a benign, rapid, and convenient synthesis of library of compounds based on privileged scaffolds 1,3-oxathiolan-5-ones and pyrazolones in excellent yields under solvent-free conditions (Schemes 1 and 3). Coupling of these can offer an extraordinary synergistic effect with greater prospectives than these components in seclusion. It offers us an opportunity to make products and processes green from the beginning. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of nanocatalyst ZnS and Co doped ZnS NPs have been synthesized at room-temperature via a facile and environmentally benign green aqueous chemical method [45,46] with excellent catalytic properties and high stability. We have chosen this process because of its many advantages such as its simplicity, easier composition control, better homogeneity, easier fabrication of plenty nanoparticles, lower cost, possibility of using high purity starting materials, easier scaling up for large scale synthesis without using high pressure, temperature and toxic chemicals. 2.2 XRD Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of both the pure ZnS and Co doped ZnS NPs. From Fig. 2, it is also noticed that three diffraction peaks appearing for all the samples at 2Î¸ values of about 28.5, 47.53 and 56.34 correspond to (002), (110) and (200) planes of hexagonal phase of ZnS respectively. Co alloying into ZnS did not create any phase change [44,47]. The XRD data was refined by removing the broadening due to instrument and non uniform strain present in the lattice. The particle size was calculated using the Scherrer's formula [48]. The Scherrer formula is given by: (1) D = 0.9 Î» Î² c o s Î¸ where D is the average particle size perpendicular to the reflecting planes, Î» is the X-ray wavelength, Î² is the full width at half maximum (FWHM), and Î¸ is the diffraction angle. The average particle size for pure ZnS and Co doped ZnS has been found to be 5nm and 4nm respectively. 2.3 TEM Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of both the samples. From Fig. 3, it is clear that the so-prepared ZnS and Co doped ZnS samples have their sizes in the nano regime. The nanoparticles are approximately spherical in shape and aggregate a little, whose size distribution is given by the histogram (Fig. 4 ). It can be seen that all the nanoparticles have an average size in the 4â8nm range, which is consistent with the results obtained through the calculation by Scherrer's equation. 2.4 EDAX EDAX has been employed to confirm the Co doping. Fig. 5 shows the EDAX of both the samples. The EDAX of Co doped ZnS NPs sample depicts the successful doping of Co in the lattice of ZnS nanoparticle. Dopant concentration of the catalyst was also be confirmed by ICP-AES analysis. 2.5 UV-spectra The absorption spectra of Co doped ZnS and pure ZnS samples have been recorded in the 250â650nm range at room temperature and have been shown in Fig. 6 . From Fig. 6, it is observed that the absorption edge shifts toward the lower value of wavelength (higher energy) with the doping of metal (Co). This slight shifting in absorption edge is the outcome of the quantum confinement effect produced due to increased nucleation rate with doping. The trend of band gap variation after doping observed in present study is similar to that reported earlier [48]. 2.6 Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis Co doped ZnS nanoparticles were dissolved in HNO3, diluted and analyzed with ICP-AES. From ICP-AES analysis cobalt concentration in ZnS nanoparticles was found to be 3.07%. Element symbol Concentration (%) Co 3.07 2.7 Surface acidity measurements The surface Lewis acidity was confirmed through the adsorption of pyridine vapors [49,50] on the surface of the NPs. FT-IR spectra of pyridine adsorbed on the catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . The band at around 1400cmâ1 is attributed to adsorbed pyridine at the surface Lewis acid site. The intensity of this band increases with Co doping. Thus it indicates the presence of considerably strong Lewis acid sites at the surface of Co doped ZnS NPs. 2.8 IR-assisted pyrazolones synthesis using nanocatalyst in solvent-free conditions We began our study by evaluating the efficiency of IR in the reaction between phenyl hydrazine (1mmol), 1 and ethyl acetoacetate (1mmol), 2 in solvent-free condition to obtain the pyrazolone 3a. Initially, the mixture was treated with an infrared irradiation (360W) at 140Â°C under neat conditions for 10min. However the results demonstrated the need of a catalyst. Thus in order to develop a feasible approach, we chose various catalysts to be analyzed in this cyclocondensation reaction. Among the various catalysts given in Table 1 , ZnS NPs were found to be active in reaction with a turn-over frequency (TOF) of 123minâ1. When the Co doped ZnS NPs were used, the activity was improved to (TOF) 2736minâ1. This finding indicates that doping of Co promotes the activity and selectivity of ZnS NPs. Doping of Co in ZnS NPs increases the number of exposed metal sites [51,52] and therefore improves the metal-time yield and also increases the reaction rate per exposed metal site, that is, the turnover frequency. To investigate the effect of catalyst loading, the model reaction was carried out in the presence of different amounts of catalyst. The best result was obtained in the presence of just 5mol% cobalt doped ZnS NPs, and with excessive amount of catalyst there was a drop in the yield. This drop may be attributed to the coagulation of nano particles, which decreased the effective surface area of the catalyst (Table 1). It was proved that the catalyst did play an important role in this reaction. This result indicated that the catalytic activity should be directly proportional to the number of surface acid sites, which are the ones accessible to the reactants. Therefore, the lower catalyst loading is required for this transformation as compared to many other catalytic systems. In order to develop a viable approach, the model reaction was investigated under different nonconventional and conventional conditions and the overall findings are given in Table 2 . Under IR, the catalytic activity of Co doped ZnS NPs was found to be 40-fold higher than the conventional method. The enhancement of catalytic activity might be due to the fact that infrared acted directly on the nanocatalyst because of its excellent infrared-absorbing ability [53,54], which created a compatible system for both the substrate and the product, and prevented the deactivation of nanocatalyst during the reaction. Nanocatalyst can play a dual role of catalyst as well as susceptor, and enhance the overall capacity to absorb IR in the reaction mixture. The model reaction was also studied by varying infrared power (180, 270, 360, and 450W) and it was concluded that 360W power output at 140Â°C was required to accomplish maximum conversion to product 3. The reactions were repeated in infrared source to prove reproducibility, and no significant deviation was found. The general efficiency of this protocol was then studied for the synthesis of a variety of pyrazolones and the results are summarized in Table 3 . As it can be seen from Table 3, various hydrazines reacted efficiently with 1,3-diketones to afford the desired pyrazolones in good yields. A variety of substituents on the aryl ring including halogens, NO2, etc. were well tolerated (Table 3). Moreover, we also examined the condensation of aliphatic hydrazide with 1,3-diketone. Similarly, the corresponding product was obtained with good yields. Encouraged by the results obtained, reaction was also conducted with heterocyclic 1,3-diketones and in this case, yield of the product was 95%. To examine the feasibility of a relatively large-scale synthesis, a mixture containing 20mmol of each of the two reactants was subjected to the reaction conditions leading to isolation of more than 90% of 3a. The present NPs catalyzed the reaction of hydrazines with Î²-ketoesters proceeds via regioselective attack of the least hindered nitrogen atom [55] of 2 on the ketone moiety of 1 followed by intramolecular cyclization involving the ester and the second nitrogen atom of hydrazine moiety to provide compound 3 with no evidence of formation of the other regioisomeric derivative 3â². The NPs facilitate the condensation reaction through Lewis acid sites of nanoparticles coordinated to the oxygen of carbonyl groups, which facilitates the nucleophilic attack from the nucleophile (NH2 group). In addition, the doping further increases the Lewis acidity of the Nps, thus making the carbonyl group more susceptible to nucleophilic attack (Scheme 2 ). 2.9 IR-assisted 1,3-oxathiolan-5-ones synthesis using nanocatalyst in solvent-free conditions After the establishment of the best conditions for the synthesis of pyrazolones 3, we decided to extend the synthetic scope of this protocol for the synthesis of 1,3-oxathiolan-5-ones derivatives (Scheme 3 ). We employed our established conditions and irradiated the model substrates, that is, benzaldehyde (1mmol), mercaptoacetic acid (1mmol) with 5mol % of catalyst in an infrared reactor (360W) at 140Â°C under neat conditions. It was found that at 140Â°C with a catalytic loading of 5mol% catalyst, irradiation with IR for 15s gave quantitative amounts of the 1,3-oxathiolan-5-one derivatives. To study the scope of this method, reactions of a variety of aldehydes with mercaptoacetic acid were run and a library of substituted 1,3-oxathiolan-5-one derivatives was obtained (Table 4 ). Both electron-withdrawing and electron-donating substituents on the aldehyde aryl ring were well tolerated. Ortho-, meta-, and para-nitrobenzaldehydes produced the desired products (Table 4) in similarly high yields indicating that the position of the electron-withdrawing substituent had no significant effect on the yield. A similar trend was observed with electron-donating substituents. Introduction of m-OH, p-Me, and p-OMe on the benzaldehyde aryl ring produced the corresponding 1,3-oxathiolan-5-one derivatives with excellent yields. Extension of this protocol to cyclic ketones was also found to be successful with good to excellent yields (90â93%). The plausible mechanism for the formation of 1,3-oxathiolan-5-one derivatives is depicted in Scheme 4 . The NPs facilitate the condensation reaction through Lewis acid sites of nanoparticles coordinated to the oxygen of carbonyl groups, which facilitates the nucleophilic attack from the nucleophile (SH group). In addition, the doping further increases the Lewis acidity of the Nps, thus making the carbonyl group more susceptible to nucleophilic attack. 2.10 Recyclability of nanocatalyst The recyclability of the catalytic systems has been investigated (Fig. 8 ). The catalysts were recovered by a simple work-up using the sonication method. A new reaction was then conducted with fresh reactants under similar conditions. It was found that the developed catalyst could be used at least four times without any change in activity. The prepared nanoparticles could be stored in absolute ethanol or as dry powder under N2 an atmosphere of N2 for a long period. The advantage of the nanoparticles is that unlike other catalysts, their use is not restricted by their solubility, since the nanoparticles can be dispersed in the desired solvent by agitation or slight sonication. The TEM and XRD analysis of the nanoparticle revealed that the morphology of the recovered NPs remains unaltered during the recycling process, which indicates that the catalyst is stable toward oxidation during the reaction. ICP-AES analysis shows that no leaching of nanocatalyst was detected in the final product upon recycling of the catalyst (see Supporting Information). Supplementary material related to this article found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2013.02.010. 3 Experimental 3.1 General All the experiments were carried out in atmosphere. All commercial starting material and reaction reagent were used as received. In general, solvents were re-distilled prior to use in the reactions, and deposited under an atmosphere of nitrogen. IR spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu FT IR-8400S spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. 1H, 13C spectra were recorded in DMSO-d6 using TMS as an internal standard on a Bruker spectrophotometer at 300/400 and 75/100MHz respectively. Mass spectrums of representative compounds were recorded on JEOL SX-102 spectrometer at 70eV/WATERS Xevo-Q-TOF. Melting points were recorded on a Toshniwal apparatus and are uncorrected. Sonication was carried out using an ultrasonic processor probe (Processor SONOPROS PR-1000 MP, OSCAR ULTRASONICS with power input 230V, 50Hz, 4A and power variac 0â230V and 3A) operating at 20kHz, 750W with 12mm tip diameter probes. The microwave-assisted reactions were carried out in a MAS-II microwave oven (2450MHz, Sineo Microwave Chemistry Technology Company, Shanghai, China) with a maximum power output of 1000W. This system is equipped with a power and temperature feedback control switch. The infrared irradiation was performed using IR lamp integrated to a modified infrared reactor [56,57]. The reactor had a maximum output of 540W, equipped with a 6 power levels and time controller. 3.2 Catalyst preparation Nanoparticles of ZnS were prepared at room temperature by dropping simultaneously 50ml of 1M solution of ZnSO4 and 50ml of 1M solution of Na2S into 200ml of distilled water containing 50ml of 0.1M solution of EDTA, which was vigorously stirred using a magnetic stirrer under an atmosphere of Ar. The high insolubility of ZnS formed out of the chemical reaction caused the formation of a number of new nuclei while preventing the growth of already existing ones, thus limiting the particle size. The role of EDTA was to stabilize the particles against aggregation, which may lead to an increase in the particle size. The doping of Co has been done by adding 3wt% of metal sulfate (CoSO4) to ZnSO4 (at the starting of the reaction) for the formation of ZnS:Co NPs. The precipitate was separated from the reaction mixture and dried at room temperature. After sufficient drying, the precipitate was crushed to fine powder with the help of mortar and pestle. 3.3 Catalyst characterization The wide angle X-ray diffraction pattern of the sample was obtained using BraggâBrentanno geometry on Panalytical Xâpert Pro diffractometer in 2Î¸ range of 15â85Â° with Cu KÎ± radiation source (Î» =1.5406Ã). The X-ray tube was operated at 45kV and 40mA. TEM measurements of the sample were carried out using a JEOL â transmission electron microscope. Sample for the TEM was prepared by making a clear dispersion of nanoparticles in dimethyl formaldehyde and placing a drop of it on a carbon coated copper grid. The EDAX measurements of the synthesized nanoparticles were performed to confirm the copper doping using a FEI Quanta 200F SEM fitted with an EDAX. The optical absorption spectra of the nanoparticles were recorded using ocean optics USB 2000 spectrophotometer in the solution form. 3.4 Pyrazolones synthesis using nanocatalyst A mixture of phenyl hydrazine (1mmol), ethyl acetoacetate (1mmol), and cobalt doped ZnS NPs (5mol%) which was taken in a Borosil beaker. The reaction mixture was homogenized with the help of a glass rod and irradiated in an infrared reactor (360W). The progress of the reaction was checked on TLC. After completion, the reaction mixture was cooled at room temperature. The resultant material was diluted with water and extracted with ethyl acetate. The organic layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4, and the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure to yield the crude product, which was then purified by recrystallization from hot ethanol. Nanoparticles were recovered by sonication of aqueous layer and reutilized four times for the same reaction. 3.5 1,3-Oxathiolan-5-ones synthesis using nanocatalyst A mixture of benzaldehyde (1mmol), mercaptoacetic acid (1mmol), and cobalt doped ZnS NPs (5mol%) which was taken in a Borosil beaker. The reaction mixture was homogenized with the help of a glass rod and irradiated in an infrared reactor (360W). The progress of the reaction was checked on TLC. After completion, the reaction mixture was cooled at room temperature. The resultant material was diluted with water and extracted with ethyl acetate. The organic layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4, and the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure to yield the crude product, which was then purified by recrystallization from hot ethanol. Nanoparticles were recovered by sonication of aqueous layer and reutilized four times for the same reaction. 3.6 General procedure for the recyclability of the catalyst After completion, the reaction mixture was cooled at room temperature. The resultant material was diluted with water and 10ml of ethyl acetate was added to the reaction mixture. The reaction mixture was sonicated until complete dissolution of products in ethyl acetate was observed. The two layers were then separated. The aqueous layer was sonicated for 5â10min and reutilized for the same experiment for over four cycles. 4 Conclusion Cobalt doped ZnS NPs catalyzed novel strategy has been developed to generate a diverse array of pyrazolones (with excellent regioselectivity) and 1,3-oxathiolan-5-one derivatives, each representing a privileged medicinal scaffold using infrared irradiation as the heating mode. The proposed synthetic protocol allowed a straightforward preparation of an array of molecules spanning a broad range of molecular diversity. About 40-fold higher catalytic activity was observed for nanocatalyst under IR than that under conventional method. The results suggested that IR and nanocatalyst had a synergistic effect. Catalytic processes with shorter reaction times safeguard the catalyst from deactivation and decomposition. The positive effect of cobalt doping in catalyst ZnS NPs on reaction rate acceleration was attributed to an increase in surface acidity. Elimination of corrosive liquid acids, conventional organic solvents, and toxic reagents, recycling and economic viability of the catalyst, atom-economy, low catalyst loading, broad substrate applicability and formation of water as the only by-product are additional advantages of the present methodology relevant to green chemistry. Further exploration of the cobalt doped ZnS NPs and biological evaluation of the synthesized libraries are in progress and will be reported in due course. coredata.dc:description: This paper reports preparation and characterization of cobalt doped ZnS NPs and their catalytic application in the synthesis of heterocyclic privileged medicinal scaffolds involving pyrazolones (with excellent regioselectivity) and 1,3-oxathiolan-5-one frameworks under infrared irradiation. Nanoparticles have been prepared at room temperature by a wet chemical method. The heterogeneous catalysts were fully characterized by XRD, TEM, EDAX, ICP-AES and UV/Vis. Under infrared radiation (IR), the catalytic activity of Co doped ZnS NPs was about 40-fold higher under IR as compared to the conventional method. Nanocatalyst plays a dual role of catalyst as well as susceptor, and enhances the overall capacity to absorb IR in the reaction mixture. Doping by Co promotes the activity and selectivity of ZnS NPs as indicated by their high TOF value, providing the products with good to excellent yields. The surface acidity of NPs was measured by FTIR spectra of chemisorbed pyridine. The present method does not involve any hazardous organic solvent or catalyst. The introduction of nanocatalyst in an IR system offers promising features for the reaction response such as the shorter reaction time, simple work-up procedure, and purification of products by non-chromatographic methods. The catalyst was reused up to four runs without an appreciable loss of catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Cobalt doped ZnS nanoparticles as a recyclable catalyst for solvent-free synthesis of heterocyclic privileged medicinal scaffolds under infrared irradiation
